h i g h l i g h t s
Mechanical properties of HSC containing PP, MP and hybrid fibers with nano-silica and silica fume were studied. The optimum percentages of fibers and pozzolans were selected and employed in producing high-strength concrete. Introducing nano-silica and silica fume improved mechanical properties and durability of concrete. Substitution of MP with PP fibers reduced mechanical properties of concrete. High volume fractions of PP fiber brought about negative effects on mechanical properties of HSC.

a b s t r a c t
The current study investigates the effects of different amounts of polypropylene (PP) and macropolymeric (MP) fibers on the mechanical properties and durability of high-strength concrete containing silica fume and nano-silica. In total, 280 concrete specimens were produced in 28 different test groups, for which the parameters of compressive strength, tensile strength, modulus of elasticity, water absorption, and porosity were evaluated. The macro-polymeric fibers in volume fractions of 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0, and 1.25%, and the polypropylene fibers in volume fractions of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5% were used in this study. Furthermore, one set of specimens with the total fiber volume fraction of 1.0% of the concrete volume was tested in order to examine the effect of hybrid polypropylene-macro-polymeric fibers on the concrete properties. In addition, the nano-silica with the weight percentages of 1, 2, and 3%, and the silica fume with the weight percentages of 8, 10, and 12% were employed in the concrete mix design. In the current paper, first, the effects of macro-polymeric, polypropylene, and hybrid fibers on the physicomechanical properties were comparatively examined, and then the influence of using nano-silica and silica fume in the high-strength concrete with no included fiber was investigated. Finally, the optimum percentages of fibers and pozzolans corresponding to the most significant increases in the tensile strength were chosen, which were subsequently used as the optimum combination of the highstrength concrete. The results of the experimental study suggest an improvement in the concrete mechanical properties and durability following the introduction of nano-silica and silica fume. In addition, incorporating macro-polymeric fibers in the concrete mixture given the volume content of fibers improves the mechanical properties of high-strength concrete. Moreover, high volume fractions of polypropylene fibers in the concrete mixture brought about negative effects on the physicomechanical properties of the high-strength concrete.

sections.heading: 1.1. Fiber-reinforced concrete
sections.text:
Normal concrete is a composite material with low tensile strength and strain ranges [1,2]. Two main weaknesses of concrete, namely its brittle behavior and its weakness under
tension, which lead to low ductility, have posed problems for the structural application of normal concrete. Generally, the addition of fibers to the concrete mixture can significantly improve the concrete mechanical properties [3–6]. The presence of abundant micro-cracks throughout the concrete body even before the beginning of tensile testing prevents the appropriate transfer of tensile stress during the test that leads to the crack widening. As a result, the application of fibers to compensate for the weakness in the tensile and ductile behavior and to obtain a concrete with less cracking seems evident, with the extent of behavioral improvement being strongly dependent on the type, shape, and percentage of fibers [7,8]. The appropriate types of fibers to produce fiber-reinforced concrete may include steel, glass, synthetic, and natural fibers, among which the synthetic fibers are divided into two groups considering their diameter, i.e. the fibers with the equivalent diameter more than and those with the equivalent diameter less than 0.3 mm referred to as macro-synthetic and micro-synthetic fibers, respectively [9]. Micro- and macro-synthetic fibers deal with micro- and macro-cracks, respectively, and some research has been performed to introduce macro-synthetic fibers as a steel fiber-replacement in shotcrete and other structural applications [10–12]. Depending on their shape and geometry, the fibers are capable of considerably enhancing the ductility, impact resistance, fracture energy, fire resistance, and durability of concrete [11,12]. Due to their low modulus of elasticity relative to that of steel fibers as well as their crimped shape, macro-synthetic (macro-polymeric) fibers demonstrate higher deformation at peak load, toughness, post-cracking loadcarrying capacity, and reduced crack width [13]. Among various fibers, macro-polymeric and polypropylene fibers as synthetic fibers have been attracting increasing attention of researchers due to their lower cost and weight, resistance against corrosion and acids, excellent toughness, and enhanced shrinkage cracking resistance [14,15]. In general, reinforcing concrete with one type of fibers improves the concrete characteristics in a limited range. In contrast, hybrid fiber-reinforced concrete with two or more fiber types may be a better option for presenting enhanced properties. Since the cracks in concrete occur in various sizes and loading stages, employing various types of fibers with different lengths is an appropriate way to prevent macro- and micro-cracks propagation [16–19]. However, research on the macro-polymeric and hybrid polypropylene-macropolymeric fibers is scarce in the literature.
In their study, Kun-Yew et al. [20] added different types of polypropylene fibers in the concrete volume, and enhanced the mechanical properties such as tensile and flexural strength, and modulus of elasticity. Moreover, the use of 0.5% volume fraction of polypropylene fibers resulted in 95.8% reduction in the slump. The effects of fiber hybridization on the tensile behavior of ultrahigh performance hybrid fiber-reinforced concrete were investigated in the work of Park et al. [21], in which four types of macro-steel fibers with different shapes and geometries as well as one type of micro-steel fibers were utilized. Their results revealed that using different types of fibers in the concrete prevented micro-crack and macro-crack propagation, and compensated for the concrete weakness in tension. Afroughsabet and Ozbakkaloglu [22] studied the effect of hybrid fibers on the mechanical properties and durability of high-strength concrete. In their study, the hybridization of steel and polypropylene fibers with the total fiber volume fraction of 1% by volume of the concrete was investigated, and the results suggested better mechanical properties and durability of concrete for the hybrid fibercontaining specimen compared to the plain concrete. In addition, replacing steel fibers by polypropylene fibers resulted in a decrease in the strength.

sections.heading: 1.2. Nano-silica and silica fume
sections.text:
Modern developments in the field of civil engineering construction have created an urgent demand for new types of concrete with improved qualities such as high strength, toughness, and durability [23,24]. Consistent with the fast progress of the concrete technology and use of pozzolans as supplementary cementitious materials, the capability of producing high-strength concrete (HSC) and high-performance concrete (HPC) has risen accordingly [25,26]. Furthermore, considering that the high-strength concrete technology is a new development in the concrete construction industry, in order to improve concrete behavior as well as the microstructure of cementitious materials at the micro and nano levels, nanosilica and silica fume pozzolans can be used as a weight percentage of cement. Generally, the cement-replacing pozzolan in the concrete produces calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) gel during the pozzolanic reaction with the calcium hydroxide formed by cement hydration, which in turn results in higher strength and lower concrete porosity [27,28]. Today, researchers and engineers in the field of concrete technology are considering nano-silica as a new additive material of interest, since as one of the nanotechnology products, it possesses a very high amorphous silica percentage, a very large specific surface area, and very smaller dimensions in relation to silica fume. The compressive strength at the initial aging stages for the concrete containing nano-silica as opposed to silica fume is greater because of a faster and more active pozzolanic reaction as well as reduced initial hardening time. Li et al. [29] investigated and compared different percentages of nano-silica and silica fume particles by the weight of cement, and showed that adding 10% nano-silica increased the concrete compressive strength by 26% while adding the same amount of silica fume enhanced the compressive strength by 15%. Amin and Abu el-Hassan [30] investigated the effects of using various types of nanomaterials on the mechanical properties of high-strength concrete. The obtained results indicate that 3% nano-silica by the weight of cement as the optimum percentage improves the concrete mechanical properties considerably.
In the present study, the effects of using different amounts of polypropylene and macro-polymeric fibers on the mechanical properties and durability of high-strength concrete containing nano-silica and silica fume are investigated. Altogether, 28 mix designs containing different percentages of polypropylene (PP), macro-polymeric (MP), and hybrid PP-MP fibers along with different amounts of nano-silica and silica fume were prepared and used for producing concrete specimens. First, 16 mixtures were prepared and tested in order to examine the effects of PP, MP, and hybrid PP-MP fibers as well as to determine their optimum percentage. Next, in order to investigate and compare the effects of using nano-silica and silica fume on the mechanical properties and durability of high-strength concrete and to determine their optimum percentage, 6 mix designs were prepared and tested. Finally, 6 mix designs possessing the optimum percentages of fibers and pozzolans (corresponding to the most significant increases in the tensile strength) were selected and subsequently employed in producing high-strength concrete. This work investigated the physico-mechanical properties of the concrete specimens including compressive strength, splitting tensile strength, modulus of elasticity, water absorption, and porosity.

Moreover, NS and SF indicate the existence of nano-silica and silica fume in the concrete, respectively, with the number following denoting the weight percentage of the used cement-replacing pozzolan.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mix proportions of fibers and pozzolans
sections.text:
Note that fibers with high Vf values give rise to the balling phenomenon as well as problems with the concrete workability. Therefore, the polypropylene fibers were selected with the volume fractions of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5% and added to the concrete mixture. However, the volume fraction of macro-polymeric fibers negligibly affects the amount of slump due to the resilience and elastic characteristics of these fibers. In fact, in the specimens where these fibers are used, the amount of slump not only does
not decrease, but it may also become greater than that of the normal specimen. Hence, in this study, macro-polymeric fibers with the maximum volume fraction of 1.25% by the concrete volume were utilized, since the fractions greater than this value lead to porosity on the surface of the high-strength concrete. Macropolymeric fibers were selected with the volume fractions of 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.25% and added to the concrete mixture.
Different weight percentages of nano-silica and silica fume were used and investigated in this work. Nano-silica reduces the slump and workability of concrete because of its high water absorption level (due to its greater specific surface area compared to cement, and its nanometer-scale dimensions). With respect to the tests performed in the current research on the usage
percentage of nano-silica in the high-strength concrete mixture, it was observed that the amount of nano-silica above 3% volume content could not be used, since the water-to-cement ratio was low, and besides, nano-silica has a strong water reduction property that prevents full hydration reaction. Furthermore, silica fume is often used with the maximum amount of 12%, since in highstrength concrete the amount of calcium hydroxide in the concrete decreases as the silica fume increases, and in fact, with an increase in the silica fume above 12%, almost all Ca(OH)2 in the cement paste disappears. Here, 1, 2, and 3% of the cement weight was replaced by nano-silica, and 8, 10, and 12% of that was replaced by silica fume.

sections.heading: 2.3. Specimen preparation and mixing procedure
sections.text:
In order to produce the concrete containing fibers and pozzolans, first, the aggregates including sand and gravel were mixed in a mixer for 30 s. Then, the cement was incorporated with the pozzolan of interest, and the resulting combination was added to the initial mixture to be blended in the mixer for 1 min. Afterwards, a liquid mixture including the water required for raising the aggregate moisture level to the saturated surface dry condition, as well as the superplasticizer was slowly poured into the mixer for 30 s, and the mixture was stirred for 2 min. Finally, the fibers used in the mix design were added to the mixture and stirred in the mixer for 2 min. To produce plain concrete, the aggregates of sand and gravel were first mixed in the mixer for 30 s, and the cement was subsequently added to the mixture and blended for 1 min. Then, a liquid mixture consisting of water and superplasticizer was slowly poured into the mixture for 30 s, and then the resulting mixture was stirred for 2 min to achieve an appropriate workability for concrete.
After the mixing procedure, the slump values of the concrete mixtures were measured, and finally, the fresh concrete was cast into the 100 200 mm cylindrical molds in 3 layers, each compacted via 25 strokes using a compacting rod. After casting in the molds, a vibration table was utilized to further compact the concrete specimens and reduce the air bubbles trapped within them. The concrete specimens were removed from the molds after 24 h, and were then placed into a tub filled with lime-saturated water at the standard temperature of 20 C and relative humidity of 100%, and kept there for at least 28 days.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Compressive strength testing
sections.text: The compressive strength tests of the concrete specimens were carried out after at least 28 days of curing age in accordance with ASTM C39 [36]. The standard loading rate varies in the range of 0.2–0.3 MPa/s. Therefore, the loading rate in the compression tests performed on the cylindrical 100 200 mm specimens was selected as 200 kg/s, equivalent to 0.25 MPa/s.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Splitting tensile strength testing
sections.text: The splitting tensile strength tests of the concrete specimens were carried out after at least a 28-day curing age in accordance with ASTM C496 [37]. The machine utilized in the compression tests carried out this group of tests on the cylindrical 100 200 mm specimens. The standard loading rate is in the 0.7–1.4 MPa/min range, and thus the loading rate of the tensile strength test was selected as 60 kg/s, equivalent to 1.15 MPa/min.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Modulus of elasticity testing
sections.text: To determine the elastic modulus of the cylindrical concrete specimens during the compressive loading in the longitudinal direction, one could perform in compliance with the method specified by ASTM C469 [38]. The axial strain of the specimens during the compression test was determined by measuring the axial deformation at the mid-height, and their axial stress was also calculated as the ratio of the applied compressive force to the specimens’ cross section.

sections.heading: 2.4.4. Water absorption, density and porosity testing
sections.text: The water absorption, oven-dry density, saturated surface-dry density, and porosity testing of the specimens was carried out after at least 28 days of curing time accordant to ASTM C642 [39]. First, the specimen is placed in an oven at the temperature of 110 C for 24 h, and is then weighted. In the next step, the specimen is saturated in limewater for not less than 48 h, then its surface is wiped with a dry towel to remove surface moisture, and it is weighted again. After that, the specimen is placed in a suitable receptacle containing tap water, and is boiled for 5 h. After cooling to the ambient temperature and removing the surface moisture, the mass of the specimen is determined. Finally, the saturated specimen is submerged in a water tank with a cable in order to measure the apparent mass. The water absorption, oven-dry density, saturated surface dry density, and porosity (volume of permeable pore space) of the specimen are calculated using the measured masses.

sections.heading: 3.1. Slump
sections.text:
The slump values of concrete mixtures are given in Table 6. The slump test was performed in accordance with ASTM C143 with the purpose of determining the workability as well as the consistency of the fresh concrete. In general, the addition of fibers and pozzolans to concrete mixture leads to a decrease in slump [22,40,41]. The high content as well as surface area of fibers can absorb more cement paste to wrap around, which in turn leads to an increase in the viscosity and decrease in the slump of a concrete mixture [42,43]. Additionally, as the cement-replacing pozzolans, nano-silica and silica fume reduce the slump and workability of concrete due to their higher water absorption level induced by greater specific surface area as well as their much finer dimensions as opposed to cement. In this research, the slump of 170 mm was obtained for the plain concrete, and once the polypropylene and hybrid polypropylene-macro polymer fibers
were introduced, the slump decreased. Polypropylene fibers result in stiffness as well as reduced workability of fresh concrete because of the cohesion and bond they provide in the concrete mixture, while addition of macro-polymeric fibers, because of their resilience and elastic properties, has no significant effect on the slump, and may even result in higher slump compared to the plain specimen. In this study, the slump value of the fresh concrete containing macro-polymeric fibers was measured as 170 mm for all the volume fractions used. For the fresh concrete containing polypropylene fibers with the highest volume fraction, i.e. Vf = 0.5%, the slump value was reduced to 55 mm. Moreover, this value was further reduced to 50 mm for the fresh concrete containing hybrid fibers with the volume fraction consisting of 0.5% polypropylene and 0.5% macro-polymeric fibers.
For the fresh concrete containing nano-silica and silica fume with the highest weight percentages of 3 and 12% as a cement replacement, respectively, the slump values decreased to 140 and 70 mm, respectively, relative to plain concrete. In addition, in a separate test using 4.5% nano-silica, the slump was reduced to 25 mm, and by utilizing 6% of it, all the water present in the fresh concrete mixture was absorbed by the nano-silica.
With respect to the obtained experimental results, for the fresh concretes containing the optimum percentages of macropolymeric, polypropylene, and hybrid fibers in combination with nano-silica, the slump values were reduced to 135, 80, and 90 mm, respectively. Furthermore, for the freshly mixed concretes containing the optimum percentages of macro-polymeric, polypropylene, and hybrid fibers in combination with silica fume, the slump values were reduced to 110, 100, and 90 mm, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.2. Compressive strength
sections.text:
As one of the main parameters in structural design, compressive strength is undoubtedly one of the most important mechanical properties and characteristics of concrete quality. Fig. 5 and Table 7 present the compression test results performed on the concrete specimens. The concretes with the macro-polymeric and polypropylene fibers of 0.25 and 0.1% volume fraction demonstrated the maximum improving effects on the compressive strength with 8.0 and 11.5% increase, respectively. It was observed that in low volume fractions, the effect of polypropylene fibers on the compressive strength was greater in comparison with that of the macro-polymeric fibers. Generally, the improvement in compressive strength of the fiber-reinforced concrete is attributed to the ability of fibers to restrain and delay crack propagation, and to reduce the extent of stress concentration at the tip of crack [44]. Since micro-cracks are abundant throughout the concrete body, the polypropylene fibers deal with these micro-cracks better because of being micro in size as well as having smaller dimensions compared to the macro-polymeric fibers, which result in their higher efficiency in bridging micro-cracks and consequently increasing the compressive strength. However, because of their macro scale and greater length, the macro-polymeric fibers do not participate effectively in load-carrying until the peak loading point is reached; beyond which and near the moment of specimen failure is when these fibers come into play by increasing ductility and preventing further propagation of micro-cracks and cracks. Comparing the results of the fiber-reinforced concrete specimens with those of the plain concrete indicate that using fibers in high volume fractions results in a decrease in the compressive strength, which is due to fiber clumping and pore formation in the fiberreinforced concrete.
Among various hybrid fiber-reinforced concrete specimens, the one containing a combination of 0.9 and 0.1% of macro-polymeric and polypropylene fibers, respectively, demonstrated the highest
positive effect on the compressive strength with 4.2% improvement. Furthermore, the results showed that by substituting a portion of macro-polymeric fibers by polypropylene fibers while maintaining the overall 1.0% volume fraction of fibers in the concrete volume, the compressive strength experienced a decrease.
The research results of Afroughsabet and Ozbakkaloglu [22] on the effects of hybrid steel-polypropylene fibers on the highstrength concrete indicated a similar reduction in the compressive strength through replacing a portion of the steel fibers by polypropylene fibers.

Adding a limited amount of nano-silica and silica fume to the concrete matrix improves the bond between the hydrated cement paste and the aggregates, while at the same time increases compactness and decreases the porosity of specimens due to the higher specific surface area and much smaller dimensions of these admixtures in relation to cement [45,46]. However, because of their high water absorption level, high amounts of these two pozzolan types lead to an incomplete hydration reaction as well as a reduced compressive strength improvement (e.g. 3% nano-silica in the present study). The experimental results achieved demonstrate that the silica fume has a greater influence on the compressive strength of high-strength concrete in comparison with that of the nano-silica. The difference observed in the compressive strength improvement of the pozzolan-containing specimens can be attributed to the pozzolanic reaction. Nano-silica has a stronger pozzolanic reaction compared to silica fume; however, in this study, since a small percentage of nano-silica in relation to silica fume was used, the effect of silica fume on the concrete compressive strength was greater.
Considering Table 7, it is found that by combining the optimum percentage of the polypropylene fibers with that of the nano-silica (PP0.2NS3), and by combining the optimum percentage of the hybrid fibers with that of the nano-silica (PP0.1MP0.9NS3), the compressive strength is improved compared to the plain concrete and the concretes containing the optimum percentage of nanosilica and the fibers individually. Nevertheless, as can be seen,
the compressive strength of the concrete mixture containing a combination of the optimum percentages of macro-polymeric fibers and nano-silica pozzolans (MP1.25NS3) decreased compared to that of the mixture with the optimum percentage of nano-silica, which is due to the greater length and higher volume fraction of fibers as well as the pores formed by them. However, the compressive strength of this mixture exhibited an improvement relative to the plain concrete and the one containing the optimum percentage of macro-polymeric fibers. The specimens containing the optimum percentage of nano-silica together with 0.2% polypropylene and 1.25% macro-polymeric fibers with an increase of 13.5 and 6.4%, respectively, compared to the plain specimen demonstrated the highest and lowest effect on the compressive strength improvement. Moreover, as can be seen in Table 7, by combining the optimum percentages associated with the fibers and silica fume, the compressive strength increased relative to that of the plain concrete and the concretes only containing the fibers; the reason to which can be attributed to the compactness and reduced porosity of the specimens due to silica fume utilization. The specimens containing 10% silica fume combined with 0.2 and 1.25% volume contents of polypropylene and macro-polymeric fibers, respectively, demonstrated the greatest and smallest influence on the compressive strength improvement with 28.5 and 20.1%, respectively, increase relative to the plain concrete.
The cracking behavior of the various concrete specimens is given in Table 7 as Slight, Severe, and Very severe, which represent ductile, brittle, and very brittle fractures, respectively. As can be seen in the table, high percentages of nano-silica as well as all the percentages of silica fume resulted in a brittle or very brittle fracture in the concrete specimens lacking fibers, while the presence of fibers in pozzolanic concretes led to a ductile fracture.

sections.heading: 3.3. Splitting tensile strength
sections.text:
The results of the splitting tensile strength belonging to the specimens containing various fibers, the ones containing nanosilica and silica fume, and those with fiber-pozzolan combination are presented in Fig. 6 and Table 8. The results of the fiberreinforced concrete show that using the fibers, in particular, the macro-polymeric fibers, because of their presence in the brittle cement matrix, leads to a reduction in crack width and a subsequent increase in the splitting tensile strength. The tensile strength of the concrete specimens with 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.25% macropolymeric fibers exhibited an increase of 8.06, 8.44, 9.73, 18.66, and 27.45%, respectively. However, increasing the volume fraction of polypropylene fibers only up to 0.3% improved the splitting tensile strength. The tensile strength of the specimens possessing 0.1, 0.2, and 0.3% polypropylene fibers improved relative to the plain concrete by 9.06, 12.81, and 10.77%, respectively, and the concrete specimens containing 0.4 and 0.5% polypropylene fibers showed a reduction in tensile strength relative to the plain concrete by 2.73 and 3.39%, respectively. With respect to Table 8, the results obtained for the hybrid fiber-reinforced concrete point to the greater influence of macro-polymeric fibers compared to polypropylene fibers in increasing the concrete tensile strength. Among the specimens containing the hybrid fibers, the specimen with 0.9% macro-polymeric and 0.1% polypropylene fibers showed the highest effect with 18.04% increase in the tensile strength, while the specimen with 0.5% macro-polymeric and 0.5% polypropylene fibers gave the highest negative effect with 8.23% decrease in the tensile strength.
The above results indicate that utilizing macro-polymeric fibers significantly improves the concrete tensile strength relative to polypropylene fibers. Due to the crimped shape of macropolymeric fibers, a strong bond is developed throughout the concrete matrix under tensile stresses. In addition, the long length and high tensile strength of macro-polymeric fibers prevent the post-cracking macro-crack propagation, and ultimately, significantly improve the tensile strength. Since the polypropylene fibers have shorter length and lower tensile strength in comparison with the macro-polymeric fibers, they effectively prevent the development of micro-cracks in the initial stages of their formation; however, after the specimen cracking, the polypropylene fibers do not completely come into play against the tensile stress, and thus have an insignificant effect on the splitting tensile strength. Up to 0.3% volume content, the polypropylene fibers resist against microcracks, and increase the tensile strength, but once the polypropylene volume fraction passes that threshold, the tensile strength decreases as a result of the pores formed by fiber agglomeration. Jiang et al. [47] in their study used basalt fibers with the lengths of 12 and 22 mm. Their obtained results suggest that basalt fibers with a longer length lead to a greater tensile strength improvement because of a more efficient bridging effect across the crack width as well as a stronger force required for pulling them out. From Table 8, it is observed that by the addition of nano-silica and silica fume to the concrete, the splitting tensile strength improves compared to the plain concrete. The splitting tensile strength of the specimens containing 1, 2, and 3% of nano-silica as a cement replacement increased by 12.96, 7.82, and 16.10%, respectively, relative to the plain concrete, and the specimens containing 8, 10, and 12% silica fume demonstrated 17.33, 28.37, and 25.17% improvement with respect the plain concrete. The observed increase in the tensile strength can be attributed to the enhanced bond between the hydrated cement matrix and the aggregates. This enhanced bond is the result of the conversion of calcium hydroxide to calcium silicate hydrates in the presence of the reactive silica. Fig. 6(d) and (e) shows that the silica fume particles have a more significant effect on the splitting tensile strength in comparison with the nano-
silica particles due to the higher percentage of silica fume used in the high-strength concrete. In addition, considering the low water to cement ratio of the high-strength concrete as well as the high water absorption level of nano-silica due to the high specific surface area, an unfinished hydration reaction is resulted, thus the specimen with nano-silica particles has a smaller influence on the strength relative to the specimen with silica fume particles.
With respect to Table 8, it can be found that by combining the fibers’ optimum percentage with that of the pozzolans, the amount of concrete tensile strength experiences an increase compared to that of the concretes containing either one of them. The combination consisting of 1.25% macro-polymeric fibers and 10% silica fume, with 36.10% improvement in the tensile strength of fiberreinforced concrete compared to the plain concrete demonstrated the highest positive effect on the splitting tensile strength of the concrete specimens. The cracking behavior of concrete specimens in the tensile strength test is given in Table 8. It is observed from the table that most of the various percentages of nano-silica and silica fume used in the fiber-lacking concrete specimens led to either severe or very severe cracking, suggesting the occurrence of brittle or very brittle fracture, while the presence of fibers in the pozzolanic and unpozzolanic specimens led to a ductile failure. This trend was also observed previously in the compressive tests.

sections.heading: 3.4. Compression-tension relationships
sections.text: The linear relationships between the tensile and compressive strength variations of the different concrete specimens in comparison with the plain concrete strength are presented in Fig. 7. Fig. 7 (a) reveals for the macro-polymeric fibers that the relationships between the variations of tensile and compressive strength are inverse relationships, and in fact, by further adding macropolymeric fibers, the tensile strength of fiber-reinforced concrete is improved relative to the plain concrete while the opposite holds for the compressive strength. Fig. 7(b) and 7c shows for the polypropylene and hybrid fibers that the tensile strength has a direct relationship with the compressive strength; hence, the variations of the tensile and compressive strength follow a similar trend. With respect to Fig. 7, it can be understood that the curve of the hybrid fiber-reinforced concrete is located somewhere in between those of the macro-polymeric and polypropylene fiberreinforced concretes. Furthermore, it can be seen that by using the pozzolan, the curve slope corresponding to the nano-silicacontaining specimens demonstrate an entirely different pattern compared to that of the silica fume-containing specimens. Moreover, when combining the optimum percentages of fibers with those of the nano-silica and silica fume, an inverse relationship between the variations of tensile and compressive strengths appears, with a descending slope for the curve.

sections.heading: 3.7. Porosity
sections.text:
The results obtained from the porosity test of the specimens based on the water absorption test are presented in Table 9. It can be observed from the results that by increasing the macropolymeric fibers content up to 0.75%, the concrete specimen’s porosity declines, while by increasing the volume content beyond that, the porosity increases. Due to the long length of macropolymeric fibers, using high volume fractions of them leads to fiber agglomeration and pore generation inside the concrete specimen, which subsequently increases the porosity. Moreover, by adding the polypropylene fibers in the concrete mixture in excess of 0.3%, the mixture loses the appropriate liquidity needed for compaction and air bubbles are confined inside due to high fiber volume content as well as workability reduction, which in turn increases the porosity after hardening. The porosity of the concrete specimens containing 0.75% macro-polymeric fibers and the ones with 0.2% polypropylene fibers were 7.43 and 7.03%, respectively, representing the lowest porosity values among different percentages of macro-polymeric and polypropylene fibers. Among the specimens containing hybrid fibers, those including 0.2% polypropylene fibers and 0.8% macro-polymeric fibers experienced the highest porosity reduction with the porosity of 7.0%.
From Table 9, it can also be found that by using the cementreplacing pozzolan, the concrete specimens’ porosity decreases considerably, which is due to the very tiny dimensions of nanosilica and silica fume particles relative to those of cement and also their property to serve as a concrete pore-filler. Among the pozzolanic specimens, the specimen containing 12% silica fume and the one containing 3% nano-silica with the porosity values of 6.53 and 6.83%, respectively, demonstrate the lowest porosity val-
ues among the similar specimens. Adding 2 and 3% nano-silica to the concrete mixture in comparison with adding 8 and 10% silica fume had a greater influence on the porosity reduction, due to the higher specific surface area and the very small dimensions of nano-silica particles. Furthermore, by combining the optimum percentages of fibers and pozzolans, the best porosity reduction performance was observed with the specimen containing 0.2% polypropylene fibers together with 10% silica fume with the porosity of 5.46% possessing the lowest porosity among the specimens.

Furthermore, Fig. 11 indicates that the density of fiberreinforced concretes containing macro-polymeric, polypropylene, and hybrid fibers decreases relative to the plain specimen, owing to the low specific gravity of fibers [20]. Among different fiberreinforced specimens lacking pozzolan, the specimen containing hybrid fibers consisting of 0.5% polypropylene and 0.5% macropolymeric fibers had the lowest density with ODD and SSD of 2374 and 2460 kg/m3, respectively. With respect to Table 9, it can be understood that employing nano-silica and silica fume as a replacement for the cement, reduces the concrete density. It is also seen in Fig. 11 that as the weight percentage of nano-silica and silica fume increases, the density of the concrete specimen declines since nano-silica and silica fume particles are more lightweight than cement particles. In addition, since nano-silica particles are more lightweight than silica fume, and considering the lower useable percentages of nano-silica in high-strength concrete, the effect of using nano-silica on the density reduction of the specimens is almost equal to the effect of using silica fume. Hence, utilizing 3% nano-silica in comparison with using 12% silica fume with an equal ODD of 2396 kg/m3 for both demonstrated the equivalent effect of the two on reducing the concrete specimen density. With respect to the results given in Table 9 and the discussion above, by combining the optimum percentages of fibers and pozzolans in use, the density of the specimens decreases. As can be seen in Fig. 11, by combining the optimum percentage of nano-silica with that of the fibers, a greater effect on the concrete density reduction is achieved compared to when a combination of the optimum percentages of silica fume and fibers is used. With ODD and SSD of 2364 and 2435 kg/m3, respectively, the combination consisting of 1.25% macro-polymeric fibers and 3% nano-silica has the strongest influence on concrete density reduction among all the specimens.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions

Based on the experimental work performed in this research, the following conclusions can be drawn:
1. Adding polypropylene (PP) fibers to the concrete mixture leads to a reduced workability of the fresh concrete while adding macro-polymeric (MP) fibers has a minimal influence on the slump. Moreover, the introduction of nano-silica and silica fume in different percentages of the cement weight decreases the concrete slump and workability. 2. Increasing the level of PP and MP fibers in the high-strength concrete leads to a reduction in the compressive strength improvement trend to such an extent that using high volume fractions of these fibers even leads to a lower concrete compressive strength relative to the plain concrete. The same trend has also been observed for the concretes containing MP-PP hybrid fibers with the increasing volume fraction of PP fibers while maintaining the overall volume fraction of fibers. 3. In low volume fractions, PP fibers have a greater influence on the compressive strength of high-strength concrete in comparison with that of MP fibers. The highest compressive strength improvement relative to the plain concrete strength belong to MP fibers with the volume content of 0.25% and PP fibers with the volume fraction of 0.1% with the compressive strength improvement of 8.0 and 11.5%, respectively, in addition to hybrid fibers consisting of 0.1% PP fibers and 0.9% MP fibers with the compressive strength improvement of 4.2%. 4. The splitting tensile strength and modulus of elasticity of high-strength concrete increase with increasing volume fraction of MP fibers up to the threshold amount used in this
study (1.25%). Furthermore, increasing the volume fraction of PP fibers up to 0.3% leads to an increase in the concrete tensile strength and modulus of elasticity, while employing higher volume fractions decreases the tensile strength and modulus of elasticity of fiber-reinforced concrete compared to the plain concrete. 5. The optimum percentage of hybrid fibers is obtained as consisting of 0.9% MP fibers and 0.1% PP fibers, which gives 18% improvement in the tensile strength in relation to the plain concrete. By substituting a portion of MP fibers with PP fibers in the overall 1% fraction of fibers, the tensile strength of the hybrid fiber concrete is reduced. Moreover, the combination of 0.3% PP and 0.7% MP fibers shows the highest improvement in the two parameters of initial and secant modulus of elasticity of hybrid fiber-reinforced concrete in relation to the plain concrete. 6. Nano-silica and silica fume with the weight percentages of 2 and 12%, respectively, exhibit the strongest influence on the compressive strength of high-strength concrete with the associated improvements of 14.0 and 41.1%, respectively. Furthermore, using 3% nano-silica and 10% silica fume with an increase of 16.1 and 28.4%, respectively, demonstrates the highest improvement in the tensile strength. 7. By using the pozzolan as a cement replacement, the modulus of elasticity of concrete increases relative to the plain concrete. Nano-silica and silica fume with the associated weight percentages of 2 and 12%, respectively, show the greatest influence on the increase of both the initial and secant modulus of elasticity of specimens. 8. Adding PP fibers in low volume fractions, and MP fibers, as well as nano-silica and silica fume pozzolans to the concrete mixture separately leads to water absorption reduction in the hardened concrete. Moreover, utilizing MP and PP fibers in low volume fractions and nano-silica and silica fume pozzolans decreases the porosity of the concrete specimens. The concrete containing the combination of 0.2% PP fibers and 10% silica fume gives the lowest water absorption and porosity percentage among all the concrete specimens. 9. Adding fibers to the concrete mixture and using pozzolan as a cement replacement lead to a lower hardened density. The combination comprising of 1.25% MP fibers together with 3% nano-silica demonstrates the greatest effect on the concrete density reduction among all the concrete specimens. 10. Combining the optimum percentage of the fibers with that of the pozzolans considerably improves most of the physico-mechanical properties of concrete in comparison with the plain concrete, and the ones containing the optimum percentage of pozzolans and fibers individually.

metadata.abstractText: The current study investigates the effects of different amounts of polypropylene (PP) and macropolymeric (MP) fibers on the mechanical properties and durability of high-strength concrete containing silica fume and nano-silica. In total, 280 concrete specimens were produced in 28 different test groups, for which the parameters of compressive strength, tensile strength, modulus of elasticity, water absorption, and porosity were evaluated. The macro-polymeric fibers in volume fractions of 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0, and 1.25%, and the polypropylene fibers in volume fractions of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5% were used in this study. Furthermore, one set of specimens with the total fiber volume fraction of 1.0% of the concrete volume was tested in order to examine the effect of hybrid polypropylene-macro-polymeric fibers on the concrete properties. In addition, the nano-silica with the weight percentages of 1, 2, and 3%, and the silica fume with the weight percentages of 8, 10, and 12% were employed in the concrete mix design. In the current paper, first, the effects of macro-polymeric, polypropylene, and hybrid fibers on the physicomechanical properties were comparatively examined, and then the influence of using nano-silica and silica fume in the high-strength concrete with no included fiber was investigated. Finally, the optimum percentages of fibers and pozzolans corresponding to the most significant increases in the tensile strength were chosen, which were subsequently used as the optimum combination of the highstrength concrete. The results of the experimental study suggest an improvement in the concrete mechanical properties and durability following the introduction of nano-silica and silica fume. In addition, incorporating macro-polymeric fibers in the concrete mixture given the volume content of fibers improves the mechanical properties of high-strength concrete. Moreover, high volume fractions of polypropylene fibers in the concrete mixture brought about negative effects on the physicomechanical properties of the high-strength concrete. 2016 Elsevier Ltd.
